Chapter 21: Practicing austerities
Because he was having his son followed by spies, Suddhodana (Zas gtsang) learnt that the Bodhisattva was living and traveling on his own without a single attendant to wait on him.
column8: དེ་ནས་ནགས་གཅིག་ཏུ། འཁོར་ལྔ་དྲུང་ན་ཡོད་ཅིང་། གཞན་མི་མང་པོ་ཞིག་ལྡོག་འགྲོ་བ་འབྲི། དེ་ནས་ཆུ་ཀླུང་ནེ་རཉྫ་ནའི་འགྲམ་མཐའ་ནགས་ཀྱི་སྐོར་བའི་ནེའུ་གསིང་གི་དབུས་ཤིང་དྲུང་གཅིག་ཏུ་དཀའ་ཐུབ་མཛད་པའི་རྣམ་པ་འབྲི་སྟེ། སྤྱི་ཁྱབ་དང་འདྲ། དཀའ་བ་རྣམ་པ་དྲུག་སྦྱོད་པའི་རིམ་པ་མང་པོ་ཡོད་ཀྱང་། དེ་ཙམ་གྱི་ཆོག་པ་འདུག ཕྱུག་རྫིས་སྙན་ལ་ཤིང་འཛུགས་པ་དང་། ལྷ་གསུམ་གྱི་གཏམ་རྗེས་སུ་སྒྲོག་པ་སོགས་ཀྱང་འབྲི།
column9: In a forest, the Buddha dwells with the five disciples. Many other men leave the Buddha. Under a tree in a forest near the bank of the Nairañjanā (ne ranya+dza na), the Buddha lives an ascetic life. This is the same as in mainstream. There are actually six forms of ascetic practices, but what we have here is fine. Herders put sticks in the ears of the Buddha. Three gods spread the news.

column5: So he dispatched three hundred servants in Siddhartha’s wake; the latter’s maternal grandfather, King Suprabuddha (Legs par rab sad), saw fit to add two hundred more to that number.

Watching some five hundred men come into view from the thickets of trees, Siddhartha knew at once that in their company, it would be impossible to find the nectar of realization of which he was in search.
With a view to [eventually] instruct them, he decided to retain five of the troupe –  three from his father’s side, two from his mother’s – and sent all the others home.

Together, the six companions directed their steps towards Uruvilva (stengs rgyas), south of the kingdom of Gaya, and settled in a place where the banks of the Nairanjana stretched towards pleasant meadows edged with wide belts of diverse sweet-scented trees.
Seating himself at the foot of a tree, Siddhartha thought to himself: “I shall sit here to meditate on detachment.”

[First,] with his tongue just grazing the roof of his mouth, his teeth just touching, and his mind attentive upon his mind, the Bodhisattva mastered himself with such concentration that drops of perspiration started to ooze from every pore of his body.
Such a strictly maintained ascetic practice brought about an intolerably intense sensation in him. Even so, he persevered with enthusiasm.

Having mastered the art of perfectly controlling his body, he remained concentrated, never falling into a state of torpor. And he kept his mind composedly and steadily focused on meditation, without getting distracted.
Secondly, he focused his meditation on physical disintegration.
column12: These next austerities are an abreviation of a more numerous set described in the Vinayavastu.

column5: By dint of [much] training, he brought his breathing to a stop. All the air currents in his body raced to the crown of his head, causing unbearable agony – as if someone were driving an iron spike into it.
Even so, as before, he persevered with enthusiasm.

In the third place, the Bodhisattva effectively entered the concentration on desintegration: when he stopped himself from breathing, the [unexhaled] air burst through his two ears the way that a pair of bellows blasts air to make a forge fire blaze up.
The experience was agony but as before, the Bodhisattva persevered with enthusiasm.
Fourthly, he achieved the last and highest level of the meditation on physical disintegration and blocked all movement of air in his body, which caused his stomach to swell up.

He felt an excruciating pain in his head, and had the sensation that a steel blade was running through his entire body while it hung over a brazier. But as before the Bodhisattva persevered with enthusiasm.
In the fifth instance, the Bodhisattva ate as little as possible: he would boil a single pea, or else one grain of millet or rice and swallow the [trickle of] stock obtained.
As long as the least nutrient from that single grain remained in his body, he would not injest another thing.
The gods pleaded with him to engage in the practice which consists in taking in vital substances through the pores of one’s skin.
But the Bodhisattva reflected: “To indulge in that practice when I have given up taking all proper nourishment would be an act of hypocrisy. It would amount to cheating, to deceiving others”.
Thus he refrained from [that practice]
Although his body became blackish and rail-thin, the Bodhisattva persevered with enthusiasm as before.
He became physically so weak that his body came to resemble a dried and shrunken stalk of valerian or of the indigo plant.
His head grew scraggy, his waist tiny.
His eyes seemed to be set more deeply in their sockets and could hardly be discerned – like two stars reflected at the bottom of a deep well.
His ribs stuck out;
his spinal column, prominent and knobbly, looked like a length of twisted hair.
When he attempted to stand up, he fell forward.
Seating himself, he fell on his back. Sometimes he would have to prop up his torso, sometimes his legs – for, without support, he would collapse.
He shed body hair every time he touched his skin – each follicle smelled foul.
His once glowing complexion was now a ghastly gray.
Then, three gods appeared to the Bodhisattva. “Gautama’s black from top to toe,” the first god remarked.
“Indigo-ish,” said the second.
“Maroon,” the third ventured.
Three pictures formed in the Bodhisattva’s imagination.
“One may rub together twigs floating in water all one wants, they will never catch fire;
likewise it is impossible to liberate oneself while body and mind are racked with desire.
It’s no good if even a single piece of wood is wet to the touch:
a man who has got rid of the shackles of physical desire, but whose mind remains fettered will not be able to free himself.
On the other hand, two [dry] sticks rubbed together will eventually flare up, so much is certain.
Thus, the one who severs the chain of the physical and mental passions, will understand, see and touch enlightenment.
During the sixth stage, the Bodhisattva lay down on the coarse grass which served as his seat and let himself rest a little.
He continued to live on just one sesame seed or some other single grain, and did not allow himself a second piece until the first had been completely digested.
His body became even more skeletal but he did not increase his rations and as before, pursued his ascetic practices without growing discouraged.
During this entire period Suddhodana would daily dispatch two hundred and fifty men to keep watch over the Bodhisattva.
The city of Devadaha (Lhas bstan) too, would send the same number of spies each morning.
Hearing the news that the messengers brought day after day, the king’s fears grew and grew.
The queen’s attendants resolved that they too would sleep on coarse grass mats,
Yasodhara (Grags ’dzin ma) [herself] gave away all her jewelry and engaged in [other] such ascetic practices.

Noting that the prince’s earlier wives had now become adherents of the same ascetic practices as the Bodhisattva – anxious, too, to protect the unborn child that Yasodhara was carrying, the king decreed that [henceforth] no one should supply details of Siddhartha’s asceticism to the princess.
The messengers were told to relay their news to the monarch, and to the monarch alone.
Although much shaken by the daily accounts that he was receiving, Suddhodana showed nothing on his face; besides which, he deceived the queen’s entourage by spreading false tidings.
In the seventh phase, the Bodhisatva decided that the austerities he had imposed on himself were not enough: he needed to restrict himself to eating the most disgusting filth.
So then his meals began to consist of a tiny pellet which was a mix of dung and urine taken from a still unweaned calf.
As long as that substance had not been completely digested, he would not take in another thing.
[At times] To stretch his legs a bit, he would walk to the graveyard and sleep there, making a dead body that was turning a gruesome blue his pillow.
His own body, dried and shrunken, began to look increasingly like a skeleton.
Village children and cowherds would come to stare at him,
and would find it fun to stuff his ears with flowers and strands of wool;
they would even spear up a lump of earth with a stick and push that in until it came out of his nostrils – as well as the other way round, in which case it would escape out of his ears.
Forcing such items from one orifice to another, they would snigger: “Oh just look at this filthy old monster!” Then they would pelt him with stones and balls of mud.
The Bodhisattva seemed neither to see nor hear them.
As before he continued without flagging or losing his enthusiasm.
